questions.question_text_1: Which of the following best describes the primary advantage of asynchronous updates in web applications?
question_texts: Which of the following best describes the primary advantage of asynchronous updates in web applications?

options.option_text: It ensures that all elements of a web page are loaded at the same time.
It improves performance by allowing parts of a webpage to update withoutrequiring a full reload.
It forces the client to wait until the server responds before interacting with thepage.
It requires a high-speed internet connection to function correctly.

questions.question_text_1: A web server is handling requests and has an 8-core processor, 32 GB of RAM, and a network bandwidth of 500 Mbps. The application running on the server is capable of generating 100 HTML pages every second. Each of these pages includes an image file that is 500 KB in size. What is the maximum number of requests per second that the server can handle?
question_texts: A web server is handling requests and has an 8-core processor, 32 GB of RAM, and a network bandwidth of 500 Mbps. The application running on the server is capable of generating 100 HTML pages every second. Each of these pages includes an image file that is 500 KB in size. What is the maximum number of requests per second that the server can handle?

questions.question_text_1: The lens of an HDD can read data on the rotating disk with the speed of 36,000 bits per second. The disk is designed such that 600 bits pass under the lens for every revolution of the disk. What should be the maximum speed of the disk so that the lens does not miss any data?
question_texts: The lens of an HDD can read data on the rotating disk with the speed of 36,000 bits per second. The disk is designed such that 600 bits pass under the lens for every revolution of the disk. What should be the maximum speed of the disk so that the lens does not miss any data?

props.summary:
### Summary of Core Topics, Concepts, Principles, and Equations #### 1. **Database Systems** - **RDBMS (Relational Database Management System)**: Suitable for structured data with relationships, such as student enrollments, faculty assignments, and course prerequisites. - **NoSQL Databases**: Suitable for unstructured data, but not ideal for complex relational data. - **Graph Databases**: Useful for data with complex relationships, but not typically used for standard relational data. - **Key-Value Stores**: Suitable for simple data storage and retrieval, but not for complex queries and relationships. #### 2. **Web Development Concepts** - **Asynchronous Updates**: Improve performance by allowing parts of a webpage to update without requiring a full reload. - **HTTP Methods**: GET, POST, PUT, DELETE are HTTP request methods used for different operations on the server. - **Client-Server Model**: Differentiates between clients (users) and servers (providers of resources). - **Software Architecture Patterns**: MVC (Model-View-Controller) is a common pattern for organizing code in web applications. #### 3. **Programming Concepts** - **Decorators in Python**: Used to modify the behavior of functions. Example: ```python def update(func): def wrapper(N): out = [] for i in range(N): if i % 2 == 0: out.append(i ** 3) else: out.append(i ** 2) return out return wrapper @update def func(N): if N % 2 == 0: return N ** 2 else: return N ** 3 ``` - **Template Inheritance in HTML**: Allows for the creation of base templates that can be extended by child templates. Example: ```html {% extends "base_layout.html" %} {% block abc %}

Company Directors

  • Ram
  • Rahim
  • David
{% endblock %} ``` #### 4. **Flask and Web Frameworks** - **Flask Routes**: Define how URLs are handled by the application. Example: ```python @app.route("/response") def get_response(): if request.args.get("n"): n = request.args.get("n") r = "" for i in range(1, (int(n) + 1)): if is_odd(i): r = r + "odd : " + str(i) + "\n" else: r = r + "even : " + str(i) + "\n" return r else: return "missing parameter 'n' with value" ``` - **Flask-SQLAlchemy**: Used for database operations in Flask applications. Example: ```python student1 = Student.query.filter_by(First_name="Karthik").first() student1.First_name = "Vikram" db.session.commit() students_list = Student.query.all() for student in students_list: print(student.First_name, student.Last_name) ``` #### 5. **Performance and Hardware Constraints** - **Server Performance**: Calculating the maximum number of requests a server can handle based on hardware constraints (CPU, RAM, bandwidth). - **Equation**: Maximum requests per second = Minimum (CPU capacity, RAM capacity, Bandwidth capacity) - Example: If a server can generate 100 HTML pages per second and each page includes a 500 KB image, the bandwidth constraint would be: \[ \text{Maximum requests per second} = \frac{\text{Bandwidth}}{\text{Image size}} = \frac{500 \text{ Mbps}}{500 \text{ KB}} = 100 \text{ requests/sec} \] #### 6. **Hard Disk Drive (HDD) Performance** - **Disk Speed**: Calculating the maximum speed of a disk to ensure data is not missed by the lens. - **Equation**: Maximum disk speed (RPM) = \(\frac{\text{Read speed (bits per second)}}{\text{Bits per revolution}}\) - Example: If the read speed is 36,000 bits per second and 600 bits pass under the lens for every revolution: \[ \text{Maximum disk speed} = \frac{36,000 \text{ bits/sec}}{600 \text{ bits/revolution}} = 60 \text{ revolutions per second} = 3600 \text{ RPM} \] ### Mermaid Knowledge Graph ```mermaid graph TD; A[Database Systems] --> B[RDBMS] A --> C[NoSQL] A --> D[Graph Databases] A --> E[Key-Value Stores] F[Web Development] --> G[Asynchronous Updates] F --> H[HTTP Methods] F --> I[Client-Server Model] F --> J[Software Architecture Patterns] K[Programming Concepts] --> L[Decorators in Python] K --> M[Template Inheritance] N[Flask and Web Frameworks] --> O[Flask Routes] N --> P[Flask-SQLAlchemy] Q[Performance and Hardware Constraints] --> R[Server Performance] S[Hard Disk Drive Performance] --> T[Disk Speed] ``` ```mermaid graph TD; B[RDBMS] --> U[Structured Data] B --> V[Relationships] C[NoSQL] --> W[Unstructured Data] D[Graph Databases] --> X[Complex Relationships] E[Key-Value Stores] --> Y[Simple Data Storage] G[Asynchronous Updates] --> Z[Partial Page Updates] H[HTTP Methods] --> AA[GET, POST, PUT, DELETE] I[Client-Server Model] --> AB[Clients and Servers] J[Software Architecture Patterns] --> AC[MVC] L[Decorators in Python] --> AD[Function Modification] M[Template Inheritance] --> AE[Base and Child Templates] O[Flask Routes] --> AF[URL Handling] P[Flask-SQLAlchemy] --> AG[Database Operations] R[Server Performance] --> AH[CPU, RAM, Bandwidth] T[Disk Speed] --> AI[Read Speed and Bits per Revolution] ``` These graphs visually map the relationships between the core topics, providing a clear and easy-to-understand overview of the essential concepts for the exam.
